Quiz1.Question: what represents an entity in the real world that can be distinctly identified.
Quiz1.Explain: An Object represents an entity in the real world that can be distinctly identified.

Quiz1.Question: what is a construct that defines objects of the same type.
Quiz1.Explain: A Class is a construct that defines objects of the same type.

Quiz1.Question: One byte has___bits
Quiz1.Explain: One byte has 8 bits

Quiz1.Question: the answer of -24%5 in java is?
Quiz1.Explain: -24 % 5 means the remaining of the fraction

Quiz1.Question:
The following code displays ___________.
double temperature = 50;

if (temperature >= 100)
System.out.println("too hot");
else if (temperature <= 40)
System.out.println("too cold");
else
System.out.println("just right");
Quiz1.Explain: Basic if condition.

Quiz1.Question: the "less than or equal to" comparison operator in Java is
Quiz1.Explain:
Basic Java operator
<= means no more than

Quiz1.Question: What is the return type of the hashCode() method in the Object class?
Quiz1.Explain: In Java, the return type of hashCode() method is an integer, as it returns a hash code value for the object.

Quiz1.Question: The modulus operator (%) in Java can be used only with variables of integer type.
Quiz1.Explain: The modulus operator (%) may be used with floating-point as well as integer types. It returns the remainder of a division operation, e.g., 10 % 6 will return 4.

Quiz1.Question: Java is a Object-oriented programming language
Quiz1.Explain: This is a right statement

Quiz1.Question: Inside which HTML element do we put the JavaScript?
Quiz1.Explain: We put that in <Script>

Quiz1.Question: Choose the correct JavaScript syntax to change the content of the following HTML code.
Quiz1.Explain: The correct syntax to access the element is document.getElementById("example"). Here we want to access the content written under that id, so we used .innerHTML to specify that and finally we replaced the content with whatever is written inside the quotes.

Quiz1.Question: For the expression (y >= z && a == b) to be true, at least one of (y >= z) and (a == b) must be true.
Quiz1.Explain: For the result of a "&&"(aka and) operation to be true, both operands must be true.

Quiz1.Explain: Css stands for cascading styling sheet

Quiz1.Question: The == operator can be used to compare two String objects. The result is always true if the two strings are identical.
Quiz1.Explain: String objects must be compared using the "equals()" method of one of the objects
